title: Protocol to identify amino acids bound to tRNA by aminoacylation using mass spectrometry
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
The protocol below is the main part of this publication. It describes the aminoacylation reaction, the sample preparation, and the mass spectrometric analysis.
Aminoacylation reaction
Timing: 3.5 h
The aminoacylation reaction is performed according to3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] with minor modifications.
Prepare a fresh ATP solution (c = 100 mM). For this purpose, dissolve 6.0519 mg ATP in 100 μL DEPC-treated water.
Mix the reagents from Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] in the listed order to obtain a reaction mix.

The table lists the reagents and their amounts to obtain the given, final concentrations.
As a reference, prepare a second reaction mix without ArgRS (use DEPC-treated water as a substitute).
Incubate at 37°C for 3 h. During this time, arginine is attached to the 2′ OH-group of the 3′-terminal adenosine of tRNAArg.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
Sample preparation
Timing: 1 day
At this stage the other ingredients in the reaction mix besides the tRNAArg of interest preclude mass spectrometric detection. Detection of aminoacylated tRNAArg in the presence of remaining free tRNAArg is a challenge. Accordingly, the following steps describes purification and digestion of the (aminoacylated) tRNAArg. Treat each reaction mix similarly.
For purification of tRNAArg (non-aminoacylated or aminoacylated with arginine), use a RNA purification kit (PureLink miRNA Isolation Kit; Invitrogen) and follow the supplied manual (https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_microRNA_man.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_microRNA_man.pdf]; last accessed on April 20th, 2023).
Note: Use one column per reaction mix, start from step 5 in the section “Prepare bacterial lysates” of the manual mentioned above. Use a final elution volume of 50 μL.
Biotinylate aminoacylated tRNAArg according to7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] with minor modifications. Treat the reference as well.
Dissolve 6.6 mg EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-Biotin in 100 μL HEPES buffer (120 mM HEPES, pH 8.0).
Add 50 μL of the EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-Biotin solution to each purified tRNAArg sample.
Incubate at 4°C for 12–14 h.

Figure 2. Biotinylation of arginyl-tRNAArg
The figure shows the reaction of arginyl-tRNAArg with EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-Biotin. EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-Biotin reacts with primary amines7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] while the guanidine group will be unaffected.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] The resulting molecule is biotinylated arginyl-tRNAArg.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2926-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. SDS-PAGE of tRNAArg and biotinylated arginyl-tRNAArg with streptavidin attached
The gel was stained with GelRed to visualize nucleic acids (tRNAArg, A) and Coomassie Blue G250 to visualize protein (streptavidin, B). The two lanes represent an aminoacylation reaction mix where ArgRS was absent (-) or present (+). Without ArgRS, tRNAArg is not aminoacylated so that no biotinylation will occur and streptavidin cannot bind. In the presence of ArgRS arginyl-tRNAArg will be biotinylated. Streptavidin can then bind and increase the mass of the construct substantially. Nucleic acid staining shows a strong band of tRNAArg (see lane A-). This band is also present in lane A+, but with much lower intensity (remaining free tRNAArg). In lane A+, an additional band is present. Using protein stain only, this band is still observed (see lane B+) while the bands of tRNAArg are not (see lane B- and B+). Double staining reveals the presence of nucleic acids (tRNAArg) as well as proteins (streptavidin). This shows the presence of streptavidin-bound biotinylated arginyl-tRNAArg.
Note: Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] shows the reaction for arginyl-tRNAArg. In solution the NHS esters do not target the guanidine group which remains non-biotinylated.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Note: Biotinylation stabilizes the acyl bond between the tRNA and the amino acid and prevents deacylation that might occur at physiological pH.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] The free tRNAArg in the sample for reference remains non-biotinylated. In addition, biotin acts as a label for mass spectrometry.9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9],10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]

Note: At this stage, aminoacylation can be checked for. The method uses toxic/harmful chemicals. How to detect biotinylated aminoacylated tRNA using streptavidin and SDS-PAGE is presented in.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] This method can be modified by first staining the gel for nucleic acid (see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A), and subsequently for protein (see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B). Taken together this shows the presence of biotinylated, aminoacylated tRNA attached to streptavidin, corresponding to a successful aminoacylation reaction. However, it is not possible to determine which amino acids were attached to the tRNA. In addition, Moreover, it is hard to make any statements about the amounts.
Digest tRNAArg.
Add 25 μL RNase A stock solution (10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1 mM EDTA, 50% Glycerol, 4 U/100 μL RNase A) and 5 μL of ammonium acetate solution (c = 220 mM) to each sample.
Incubate at 37°C for 2 h.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2926-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Molecule of interest obtained from RNA digestion of biotinylated arginyl-tRNAArg
RNase A will cleave the tRNAArg after each C and U resulting in Cp or Up at the 3′ end of the fragment.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] During the aminoacylation of tRNAArg, the amino acid links to the CCA sequence at the 3′ end of the tRNAArg.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] Accordingly, the last cleavage site in front of the attached amino acid will be after the last C. The resulting molecule is biotinylated arginyl-adenosine. This is the molecule of interest since it will show which amino acid was attached to the tRNAArg during aminoacylation.
Note: Mass spectrometric assessments of heterogenous samples with complex ingredients in small quantities is challenging.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] Here, the digestion of tRNA enables direct detection of tRNAArg fragments12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12] (with and without attached biotinylated amino acid). No further processing of the data (e.g., deconvolution) is required so that peaks can be directly interpreted. .

Note: The molecule of interest resulting from the digestion of biotinylated aminoacylated tRNAArg is the tRNAArg fragment with attached biotinylated amino acid, biotinylated arginyl-adenosine (see Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). In the sample for reference, this molecule is missing.
Use protein concentrators (Pierce Concentrator, PES, 3k MWCO, 0.5 mL; Thermo Fisher Scientific) to separate digested tRNAArg and RNase A.
Note: Use one concentrator per sample.
Add 500 μL ultrapure water to pre-rinse the concentrator.
Centrifuge at 15,000 × g for 5 min.
Remove ultrapure water from both chambers.
Add the sample to the concentrator.
Centrifuge at 15,000 × g for 3 h. 3 h are required because of the glycerol in the RNase stock solution.
Transfer filtrated fraction to a new vial and store at 4°C.
Note: The concentrators retain RNase A. The filtrated fraction contains molecules smaller than 3 kDa and therefore the tRNAArg fragments (with and without attached biotinylated amino acid) as obtained from digestion.
Mass spectrometry
Timing: 2 h
The final step describes the mass spectrometric method identifying the amino acid of the aminoacylated tRNAArg. Detection of the tRNAArg fragment with attached biotinylated amino acid requires a LC-MS system. Here we use a HPLC system (Prominence UFLC XR System, Shimadzu) coupled with a FT-ICR-MS (7T solariX, Bruker) with ESI. Both instruments communicate via a plug-in (Compass HyStar, Bruker). The HPLC system uses a HPLC column suitable for separation of the different tRNAArg fragments (Aeris 3.6 μm WIDEPORE XB-C8 200 Å, LC Column 150 × 2.1 mm, Phenomenex).
Use two eluents (A and B).
Eluent A (HPLC grade water with 0.1% HPLC grade FA).
Eluent B (HPLC grade ACN with 0.1% HPLC grade FA).
Define a separation method for the HPLC system (Prominence UFLC XR System, Shimadzu).
Set the column oven temperature to 60°C.
Set the autosampler temperature to 7°C.

Equilibrate the column with 10% of eluent B at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min until start of the measurement.
Note: In this step and the following, only the percentage of eluent B is mentioned. The lacking percentage corresponds to eluent A.
Note: The equilibration takes 10 min. It should be performed prior to calibration of the mass spectrometer.
Use 20 μL of the sample for the measurement.
Use a linear gradient program with a constant flow rate of 0.5 mL/min for separation of the molecules in the sample.
Increase the percentage of eluent B from 10% to 30% over 10 min.
Increase the percentage of eluent B from 30% to 65% over 10 min.
Hold 65% of eluent B for 3 min.
Decrease the percentage of eluent B from 65% to 10% over 2 min.
Hold 10% of eluent B for 10 min.
Note: The last step will equilibrate the column for the next measurement.
Note: HPLC parameters may vary for other columns.
Define a method for the mass spectrometer (7T solariX, Bruker).
Use the following parameters.
Use positive mode.
Note: m/z-values represent [M + H]+.
Use a mass range from 100 to 1000 Da.
Set the capillary voltage of the ESI to 4500 V with an End Plate Offset of −500 V.
Set the Nebulizer Gas pressure to 3.0 bar.
For the Dry Gas, use a flow rate of 8 L/min and a temperature of 250°C.
Acquire single scans with a scan time of 50 ms.
Note: Parameters regarding ESI and the mass spectrometer may vary for other types of mass spectrometers.
To prevent mass drift over longer measurement periods and to maintain a high accuracy use two lock masses during measurement.

Use methyl stearate (299.294457 m/z). For the 7T solariX, apply 50 μL of a methyl stearate solution (c = 5 mg/mL) to the ceramic slides of the lock mass reservoir.
Use hexakis(2,2-difluoroethoxy)phosphazene (622.028960 m/z). For the 7T solariX, apply 50 μL of a hexakis(2,2-difluoroethoxy)phosphazene solution (c = 1 mg/mL) to the ceramic slides of the lock mass reservoir.
Note: The masses of the analytes should always be in between the two lock masses.
Calibrate the mass spectrometer.
Use a NaTFA solution (c = 0.1 mg/mL) for calibration.
Inject the solution with the syringe pump of the mass spectrometer setting a flow rate of 2 μL/min.
Acquire 64 scans with the parameters listed in 11 a.
Note: The scans must be accumulated (single scans are insufficient!).
Calibrate the mass spectrometer with the obtained spectrum.
Note: Calibration should achieve an accuracy of 1 ppm. If the error is higher, repeat the steps 12 b–12 d.
Save the calibration.
Change the 6-port diverter valve of the 7T solariX back to HPLC.
Set the number of scans to 1.
Select serial mode.
Prepare the 2 samples (digested tRNAArg; free and aminoacylated with arginine).
Use 90 μL of the filtrated fraction from step 8 f and add 10 μL of HPLC grade ACN to obtain a final ACN concentration of 10% in the sample. Add 0.1 μL of HPLC grade FA.
Vortex the sample for 10 s.
Briefly centrifuge for 10 s.
Transfer the sample to 100 μL inserts placed in HPLC vials.
Put the HPLC vials into the autosampler (pre-chilled at 7°C).
Create a sample list in Compass HyStar and select the written separation and measurement method as well as the saved calibration.
Perform a measurement on the 2 samples.
Use a suitable program (Compass DataAnalysis, Bruker) for the evaluation of the obtained data.

Recalibrate the data using the lock masses.
Extract the ion chromatogram of the analyte. The selected m/z depends on the amino acid that was attached to the tRNAArg via the aminoacylation reaction.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2926-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Molecule detected by mass spectrometry
The molecule of interest (biotinylated arginyl-adenosine) could only be detected with low intensity, however, mass spectrometry revealed the presence of biotinylated arginine exhibiting a much stronger peak. This molecule is missing in the sample for reference, showing that it originates from the purified aminoacylated tRNAArg – and not from the aminoacylation reaction mix (containing free amino acids).
Note: In the mass spectrum the expected analyte, biotinylated arginyl-adenosine (650.28274 m/z), is identified as well as biotinylated arginine (see Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]). Since biotinylated arginine was absent from the sample for reference, it must originate from biotinylated arginyl-adenosine, that is, from the aminoacylated tRNAArg. The removal of adenosine is likely due to acidic hydrolysis caused by FA in the solvent.
Note: A standard is required to confirm the m/z value of the analyte. Since a standard of biotinylated arginine is easily obtained (see step 24), we decided to focus on this analyte. However, for quantitative analysis the presence of both compounds must be considered. Here, for qualitative analysis, the analyte of interest is biotinylated arginine. Extract the ion chromatogram of biotinylated arginine (401.19655 m/z).
Note: Theoretical m/z used for ion chromatogram extraction are calculated with the IsotopePattern tool in Compass DataAnalysis (Bruker). The deviation of the measured m/z from the theoretical m/z is determined by the SmartFormula tool in Compass DataAnalysis (Bruker). It must not exceed the error of the calibration of the instrument (here 1 ppm).
Analyze the extracted peaks.
Examine the compound spectrum (The m/z deviation must not be higher than 1 ppm).

Verify that the analyzed molecule is biotinylated arginine by measurement with a suitable standard.
Dissolve 3.3 mg EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-Biotin in 50 μL HEPES buffer (120 mM HEPES, pH 8.0).
Add 50 μL of arginine working solution.
Incubate at 4°C for 12–14 h.
Measure the sample without further purification with the mass spectrometer as described in this section.
Note: The retention time and the m/z of the analyzed molecule must not significantly deviate from the standard.
